executive_summary: For-profit universities have managed to generate some revenue growth through the current period even as external challenges have weighed on the industry. While higher educational institutions have faced rising skepticism amid high student debt, for-profit universities' more affordable price tags helped them avoid more significant enrollment declines. Competition from vocational schools and other affordable alternatives pressured the industry's pricing power, but robust tuition hikes have kept revenue on a steady trajectory upward in the pandemic's aftermath. Industry revenue has ultimately swelled at a CAGR of 0.2% to an estimated $13.9 billion over the five years through 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Industry's Cheaper Price Tags Are Helping Protect It From Public Skepticism
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Ballooning student debt has made many recent high school graduates skeptical of a higher education's return on investment. While new government initiatives are seeking to improve debt-to-earnings transparency, the number of college students has sank through the current period. For-profit universities as a whole especially suffer from poor public perception, but low-income and older students commonly enroll in for-profit schools because of their lower tuition rates.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A SHAKY ECONOMIC OUTLOOK WILL BRING BACK ENROLLMENT GROWTH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Interest rates are expected to remain high through 2024 and 2025, bringing on a spike in unemployment. As competition for jobs intensifies, some jobless workers use their newfound free time to attend a for-profit university and improve their marketability to potential employers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Student Loan Relief Remains in Limbo but Could Benefit Universities
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Legislators will continue to propose new plans to address student debt following the Supreme Court's June 2023 decision to block broad-sweeping debt forgiveness for low- and middle-class borrowers. Still, multiple organizations question the legality of debt relief, and the idea faces some political roadblocks despite apparent support from the public. Proponents of student debt cancellation point to the decision's potential to bring back students who didn't complete their degrees. A resurgence in enrollment would support revenue growth for the sector as for-profit universities benefit from more government funding and more students paying tuition and mandatory fees.

industry_definition: The For-Profit Universities industry includes colleges and universities that offer academic courses at baccalaureate or graduate levels on a for-profit basis. A high school diploma or equivalent academic training is generally an admission requirement. Instruction may be provided in a variety of settings such as educational institutions, the workplace, the home, training facilities and through correspondence, TV, the internet or other electronic or distance-learning means.
key_trends: The Biden administration has revamped the gainful employment (GE) rule. Under GE doctrine, for-profit universities must report low graduate debt-to-earning ratios to qualify for federal funding. This rule will take effect in July 2024.

The opportunity cost of attending school drives the ups and downs of for-profit universities' revenue. Widespread hiring that discouraged enrollment in schools has given way to interest rate hikes, leaving for-profit universities as a reasonable option.

Debt cancellation has the potential to help the industry's public image. Smaller-scale forgiveness plans have helped some borrowers, but broad-sweeping forgiveness would boost enrollment by easing financial worries and risk aversion in would-be students.

Broad-sweeping student loan forgiveness remains in limbo. Recent initiatives, like the Saving on a Valuable Education (SAVE) Plan, help ease debt for smaller subsets of borrowers, like misled graduates of for-profit universities with high debt-to-earnings ratios.

The gainful employment rule will take effect mid 2024. Under this revamped GE rule, for-profit universities will need to report graduate debt-to-earnings ratios under 8.0% to qualify for any federal funding.

market_segmentation.segment_description: For-profit universities cater to nontraditional students who didn't begin or finish a degree in their younger years. Many students have families or part-time jobs and require a more flexible class schedule. The United States' transition to a service economy has rewarded workers with higher degrees. High layoff rates in manufacturing have encouraged middle-aged Americans to rethink their career choices and transition into the service economy and office work. Adults 30 and over boast extensive experience in their chosen fields and aren't as likely to return to higher education. Still, this demographic makes up more than half the industry's revenue because of its massive share of the US population.

Students aged 22 to 29 return to school to improve their skills to find better employment opportunities. Unlike many recent high school graduates, most people have already entered the workforce and work while attending classes. Consumers in their twenties have yet to obtain many years of experience in the workforce, so they have less to lose by returning to switching careers. Still, this segment's small share of the US population reduces its share of industry revenue.

Recent high school graduates make up a substantial share of student enrollment in for-profit universities. Many students come from low-income families that can't afford traditional four-year universities. Mounting concerns over ballooning student debt and college's return on investment have had a mixed impact on this segment's interest in for-profit universities. Many recent graduates are entering the workforce straightaway to avoid expensive tuition. Still, the industry has remained attractive to many because of its status as a cheaper option than some substitutes. Rising tuition costs at traditional four-year institutions have encouraged many recent high school graduates to enroll in relatively affordable online courses at for-profit schools. Still, for-profit universities are more expensive than other external competitors, like vocational schools and apprenticeship programs. A falling youth population means that universities' potential market has shrunk. For-profit postsecondary schools' lower costs enable them to continue expanding by stealing applicants from more expensive private non-profit universities.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Bachelor's Degrees Cater to a Wide Range of Careers
products_and_services.product_description: Bachelor's degrees are the most popular course programs for for-profit universities. These degrees take the shortest amount of time to complete and can be applied to a wide range of careers, making them useful to the broadest range of consumers.

tier_1_suppliers: Office Stationery Wholesaling in the US
Book, Magazine & Newspaper Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_buyers: Healthcare and Social Assistance in the US
Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Undergraduate courses taught at the bachelor's degree level require four years of full-time study. Students need a high school diploma or to pass the General Educational Development (GED) tests. Admission standards are less stringent than at most public universities and private colleges. Low-income and middle-aged applicants find that for-profit schools offer less expensive bachelor's programs than private non-profits. Tuition fees compare well with public universities, but for-profit schools provide unique flexibility for part-time students taking classes at night. Since recent high school graduates primarily seek bachelor's degrees, this service segment is most vulnerable to fluctuations in the high school retention rate. Stagnation in high school retention through the current period has diminished this segment's share of revenue.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Advanced Programs Offer Career Advancing Opportunities
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Master's programs involve one to two years of full-time study beyond the bachelor's degree. Most schools require a bachelor's degree from an accredited institution and completion of a standardized exam, like the Graduate Record Examinations (GRE). More students have pursued master's degrees to stand out among the growing pool of job applicants with bachelor's degrees. For-profit universities offer a low-cost and flexible option for older people in the labor force trying to improve their career prospects with an advanced degree. As the national unemployment rate has climbed, competition for jobs has become more fierce. Many have returned to for-profit universities to expand their talents and learn new skills that may not have been available while completing their undergraduate programs.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: For-Profit Schools Provide Comparable Funding for Doctoral Candidates
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Doctorate degrees are taught at the highest academic level and require mastery in a field of knowledge. Like master's degrees, the time taken to complete a doctorate varies depending on the school, program and area of study. Admission typically requires a master's degree from an accredited university. Some schools also require maintaining a minimum grade point average, relevant experience and research. Several for-profit universities offer competitive doctorate programs with competitive funding opportunities, charging tuition comparable with private non-profit schools. Applicants may choose for-profit schools after being rejected from traditional programs.

business_locations.location_description: Florida houses major for-profit universities like Full Sail universities and The Global American University Schiller in Tampa. Schools prefer the Southeast because of the low tax rates for businesses and campuses. The region's huge population, many with low incomes, pushes enrollment higher.

California has many arts and technology-focused for-profit schools, like the University of Silicon Valley and the Academy of Art University in San Francisco. These schools' proximity to fast-growing technology and entertainment companies encourages residents who move to California to enroll, particularly those who can't get in-state tuition for public schools.

business_locations.location: For-Profit Universities Don't Have to Add Campuses to Build a Nationwide Presence
business_locations.location_description: Many for-profit universities have nationwide and online presences. The University of Phoenix has 17 campuses, including schools in California and Texas.

regulations_points.regulation_description: For-profit universities must receive at least 10.0% of their revenue from sources other than Title IV funds, according to the 90/10 Rule.

In 2015, universities had to release information detailing student loan repayment rates, graduates' job earnings, education costs, average student debt levels and student withdrawal and completion rates. Schools that graduated students with high debt-to-earnings ratios couldn't receive federal student aid. After years of limbo, this policy has been cemented by the Biden administration. The Financial Value Transparency framework will go into effect on July 1, 2024, imposing a new level of regulation on for-profit universities.

In 2022, the Biden administration moved to cancel nearly $500.0 billion in student debt, up to $20,000 for eligible borrowers. This policy focuses on students from for-profit schools with high debt-to-earnings ratios. After the Supreme Court blocked broad-sweeping debt forgiveness in June 2023, smaller-scale efforts have wiped debt away for some borrowers. The latest income-driven repayment program, the Saving on a Valuable Education (SAVE) Plan, began operation in February 2024. Under SAVE, the remainder of low-income borrowers' balances are entirely eliminated.

factors_decreased_barrier: Early on, for-profit schools must find and hire professors or education professionals to help develop curriculums. The initial hiring costs take a big chunk of cash, but wages won't weigh heavily on profit as the business grows.

basis_points.basis_title: Students at for-profit schools enjoy the flexibility of online and hybrid programs
basis_points.basis_description: Students at for-profit schools enjoy the flexibility of online and hybrid programs. Students in New Jersey can easily attend classes based in other states through online degrees.

basis_points.basis_title: Public universities offer lower tuition than for-profit schools
basis_points.basis_description: Public universities offer lower tuition than for-profit schools, but in-state students benefit the most. For-profit schools stay competitive by keeping tuition below private non-profit schools and using online classes to attract out-of-state students.

basis_points.basis_title: Many for-profit schools compete in similar niche markets
basis_points.basis_description: Many for-profit schools compete in similar niche markets, like art, business or healthcare. Competition remains high even as closures reduce the number of for-profit universities in the market.

concentration_points.concentration_title: SPECIALIZED SCHOOLS COMPETE NATIONWIDE BUT IN SMALLER MARKETS
concentration_points.concentration_description: Small for-profit schools vastly outnumber multi-campus for-profit universities. Many schools provide niche courses in arts, design, business or healthcare. Specialization keeps the market fragmented and competitive because many schools offer comparable courses. Online courses enable for-profit schools to compete nationwide, eliminating geographical barriers and limiting local competition.

concentration_points.concentration_title: CLOSURES CREATE FIERCE COMPETITION AMONG THE REMAINING FOR-PROFIT SCHOOLS
concentration_points.concentration_description: Scrutiny over advertising practices, alum employment and student debt have made for-profit schools a target for regulators. Public scrutiny has also curtailed enrollment and hurt for-profit schools' reputations. Limited government funding and poor enrollment rates have forced many schools to close. Despite the industry's fragmented nature, the playing field for for-profit universities has shrunk as widespread closures have eased lessened competition.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases include dining hall services, research equipment, educational materials, and online education software
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases' revenue share has risen with investment in online learning tools and an extreme reduction in employment and wages.

Wage costs for for-profit schools lie below traditional universities because for-profit schools hire professors on a part-time basis. For-profit universities don't content with entrenched long-term costs like tenured salaries. Most wages go to recruiters who maintain and elevate enrollment levels.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Cost cutting through layoffs and wage cuts
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Cost cutting since regulations suppressed revenue growth in 2011 has come from layoffs and wage cuts. For-profit schools have routinely lowered spending on professors and staff, leaving them less vulnerable to the wage hikes associated with higher inflation.

For-profit university marketing has caused controversy as some schools now spend as much on marketing their services as they do on educational services. For-profit universities engage in marketing across all forms of media.
Insurance is an especially high expense for for-profit universities that house students on campus.
For-profit schools invest in financial aid consultants and lawyers to manage lawsuits. Schools continue to face public scrutiny and legal challenges.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Early on, for-profit schools must find and hire professors or education professionals to help develop curriculums. The initial hiring costs take a big chunk of cash, but wages won't weigh heavily on profit as the business grows.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue affected by labor market shifts
volatility_points.volatility_description: Jobs represent the most significant opportunity cost of for-profit schools. As companies hire more workers, consumers have less time to attend school. The cost of school also becomes tuition plus whatever money a student could have made working. Additionally, high unemployment means more intense competition for available jobs, so degrees have greater value to graduates.

Skyrocketing unemployment in 2020 drew a massive enrollment uptick for for-profit schools, leading to revenue and profit spikes. Continued interest rate hikes in 2024 will lift for-profit university revenue by boosting unemployment.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Bachelor's degrees cater to wide range of careers
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Bachelor's degrees are the most popular course programs for for-profit universities. These degrees take the shortest amount of time to complete and can be applied to a wide range of careers, making them useful to the broadest range of consumers.

The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

FAQs.question: As states have started putting tuition assistance plans into place, have you made changes to take advantage of this or combat this competition?
FAQs.answer: As assistance plans make colleges, particularly community and state colleges, more affordable, students are less often choosing to attend for-profit colleges, which typically charge high tuition rates.

FAQs.question: Students often take classes for personal interest or to improve certain skills. Have you changed your offerings to adapt to changing student interests?
FAQs.answer: Schools can appeal to students by providing a wide range of courses, extracurricular activities, and value-added programs.

FAQs.question: The affordability of a college education has a significant effect on profitability. Affordability is determined by tuition costs and the level of household income. Have rising tuition costs affected your bottom line?

The Career Education Colleges and Universities, formally known as the Association of Private Sector Colleges and Universities, has 500 for-profit university members representing postsecondary education of all types, including two- and four-year degrees. Most member associations, including DeVry University and Career Education Corporation, participate in federal student financial aid programs.
FAQs.answer: The Career Education Colleges and Universities, formally known as the Association of Private Sector Colleges and Universities, has 500 for-profit university members representing postsecondary education of all types, including two- and four-year degrees. Most member associations, including DeVry University and Career Education Corporation, participate in federal student financial aid programs.

FAQs.question: For-profit universities' already high tuition rates can be a major deterrent for most potential students. Balancing tuition with revenue growth is key to success.
FAQs.answer: For-profit universities' already high tuition rates can be a major deterrent for most potential students. Balancing tuition with revenue growth is key to success.

FAQs.question: The number of tenure-track positions typically have higher salaries. Have trends in employee tenure affected salary spending?
FAQs.answer: Many institutions have transitioned toward employing part-time faculty members to mitigate labor intensity. These workers command lower wages than their more tenured counterparts and help universities save on benefit costs.

FAQs.question: Access to computers has become essential for for-profit universities, as computers are used in all aspects of college life: administration, classroom instruction and independent research. Have you increased your investment in educational technology?
FAQs.answer: Colleges and universities have invested more heavily in technology in recent years to improve the quality of their programs. These investments help attract students and justify higher tuition rates.

FAQs.question: Have you implemented online platforms to provide remote learning? How have they impacted profit?
FAQs.answer: To compete with low-cost competitors, many postsecondary schools have invested in online platforms. These platforms help for-profit universities reach new markets, like students in rural communities and students with full-time jobs. Online platforms are cheaper for for-profit universities to operate since they enable one professor to teach more students at a given time.

FAQs.question: Has funding for your institution been steady or changing in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Unlike public and private not-for-profit institutions, for-profit universities don't rely on state funding. These schools typically don't receive federal government assistance through research funding, though alumni donations and private foundations can help supplement revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you work with any advocacy groups to advance your establishment's interests?
FAQs.answer: Several industry associations provide assistance to for-profit universities, like the Association of Private Sector Colleges and Universities.

FAQs.question: In addition to wages for professors and lecturers, for-profit universities require teaching support staff and other staff involved in the upkeep of facilities. How do your wage outlays compare to your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Wages are relatively low compared with traditional universities because schools hire often professors on a part-time basis. Still, wages are by far the largest expense for the industry. This gives changes in salaries a pronounced effect on profit.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: Financing challenges may include the purchase and upkeep of an adequate number of computers, tablets, and other education equipment tools.

FAQs.question: Do you have access to financial aid from the federal government? What portion of your revenue comes from this financial aid?
FAQs.answer: For-profit schools rely heavily on students' ability to access financial aid from the federal government.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? Are you known for your reliability and performance?
FAQs.answer: The perceived value of an institution helps recruit new students and encourages post-graduation employer demand.

FAQs.question: How many online courses do you offer? How have students responded to the online courses you offer?
FAQs.answer: The ability of consumers to take courses online helps for-profit schools generate the majority of revenue through online courses.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the national unemployment rate? How will a falling unemployment rate affect your school?
FAQs.answer: In periods of high unemployment, high school graduates will stay in school and pursue higher education, boosting enrollment at for-profit universities. Conversely, adults forgo higher education when the labor market improves.

FAQs.question: How can you encourage new college freshmen to enroll in your institution? How do you market your school to high school seniors?
FAQs.answer: A rise in the number of high school graduates generally increases the number of people who enter college, causing revenue to climb.

FAQs.question: Do you regularly offer online classes to students? How has demand for these classes fared in contrast with demand for traditional classes?
FAQs.answer: Online education continues to become more popular. For-profit schools had already prepared online programs and took advantage of the situation.
